James Hardie Industries (JHX AT) - Co. FY net AUD 228.8mln vs. Prev. AUD 146.1mln Y/Y. (Newswires).

Financials - APRA proposes amending guidance on mortgage lending and has started consulting on potential revisions to its guidance on serviceability assessments related to residential mortgage loan applications, while it proposes to remove the minimum 7% mortgage rate buffer. Furthermore, APRA said the changes will likely raise the maximum borrowing capacity for a given borrower. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9984 JT) - Co. unit Sprint and T-Mobile US (TMUS) took a major step forward after the Federal Communications Commission Chairman Ajit Pai expressed support for the tie-up. However, there were also reports that the DoJ was said to be leaning against approval of the deal. (Newswires)

SOUTH KOREA

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US Commerce Department confirmed plans to revise entity list so that existing customers of Huawei can maintain their networks, while it is creating a 90-day temporary general licence for Huawei and 68 other entities until 19th August. (Newswires/CNBC)

China’s ambassador to the US Zhang Ming said China could retaliate against the US after Huawei was blacklisted and suggested the move was politically motivated as well as an abuse of export-control measures, while he added that China has unwavering resolve to defend its legitimate right and interests. (Newswires)

China's Global Times stated that Australia needs to improve relations with China and that relations are at a "low ebb", while it suggested that Australia has adopted a disappointingly hawkish and hostile approach on a number of China-related matters including the ban on Huawei's participation in Australia's 5G upgrade. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM May's spokesperson said the merits of Indicative votes on Brexit is something to be considered on Tuesday and that the government remains open to discussions with lawmakers across the house. However, there were separate reports that sources suggested Brexit indicative votes are 100% dead and buried with all focus now on the Withdrawal Agreement Bill and what the government can do to get MPs on board, according to ITV's Brand. (Newswires/Twitter) 

 

COMMODITIES

OPEC is reportedly considering delaying the date of the Vienna meeting to early July from June 25th. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US Senator Lindsey Graham said at a briefing with National Security Adviser Bolton that it is clear Iran has attacked pipelines and ships of other nations and created threat streams against American interests over the last several weeks, while he added that if the Iranian threats against American personnel and interests are activated, we must deliver an overwhelming military response. (Newswires)

Iran has increased the rate at which it enriches low enriched uranium by fourfold and said it will no longer stick to the previous 300KG production cap from the nuclear deal, while it noted that the UN watchdog has been informed on the output rise. (Newswires) 

 

US

US Democrats are reportedly closer to viewing Trump’s tax record after a US judge ruled in favour of the House panel which is seeking financial records from his accounting firm. (Newswires)

Former White House counsel Don McGahn is emerging as a central witness in House Democrats' probe of possible obstruction of justice. However, there were also reports that McGahn is said to have been directed to follow a Justice Department opinion that he should not testify before the House Judiciary Committee, according to White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders. (Newswires)

Fed's Bullard (Dove, Voter) said the US economy is performing quite well and that he would be more aggressively in favour for lowering rates if inflation remains at 1.6%. (Handelsblatt)

Fed’s Bostic (Non-Voter, Dove) said the US economy will continue to perform with solid growth this year. Bostic also commented that he doesn’t expect a rate cut to be imminent and does not see one by September, nor is he tilted towards either a cut or a hike. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

T-Mobile (TMUS) and Sprint (S) jumped higher at the open on the news that the two telecoms cos are to offer concessions to the US Government to help secure regulatory approval for their planned merger which could include asset sales and rural-service guarantees. The two stocks later saw some downside on reports that the DoJ is to stand against the approval of the merger, but ultimately both stocks finished the session higher. Vodafone (VOD) and Verizon (VZ) moved higher in sympathy. United Parcel Services (UPS) saw some downside after reports emerged that SCOTUS denied a hearing for the co over Postal Service delivery prices. Cisco (CSCO) was unable to recover premarket losses despite news emerging that the held preliminary acquisition talks with cloud start-up HashiCorp, but did perform better than the majority of the Semiconductor sector. Nielsen (NLSN) spiked higher as news emerged that the co are said to be looked at by private equity, sources say; deal in high 20s seen as very likely, and could come in a few weeks. Apple (AAPL) opened lower after HSBC lowered its profit target for the co, citing renewed China growth risk and the negative impact of tariffs. Intel (INTC), Qualcomm (QCOM), ASML Holdings (ASML), Xilinx (XLNX) all opened lower as the semiconductor index suffered on renewed worries regarding the US/China trade dispute. Broadcom (AVGO) opened lower with the wider semiconductor industry, and saw further downside on reports that chip sales are being probed by the US FCC, with the probe focusing on its WiFi and Switch-Chip sales. Baidu (BIDU) took a hit as Susquehanna slashed their price target for the Co. S&P 500 -0.7% at 2840, NASDAQ-100 -1.7% at 7377, Dow Jones -0.3% at 25680.

Overnight, a better than expected Japanese GDP report for Q1 lent negative ticks in the Treasury complex, and while buyers stepped in at the European open, following more global trade tensions related news flow, the positive start for European equities capped hte Treasury upside, and futures were flat as NY entered. The complex then began its gradual drift lower, and are heading into APAC lower, led by the belly; major curve spreads were mixed into the close, but moves were +/- 1bps or so. US T-Note futures settled ticks 6+ lower at 124-09.

US MARKET WRAP 20 MAY 2019: Semiconductors hit on trade concerns; traders cautious ahead of big week for Central Banks
content:
* SNAPSHOT: Equites down, Treasuries down, Dollar flat, Crude mixed.

* REAR VIEW: Tensions escalate between US/Iran, Semiconductor and tech sectors hit on trade war concerns, Conservatives win in Aussie election surprise, Modi to win India elections, Fed speak delivers few surprises.

* COMING UP: RBA May Meeting Minutes, US Existing Home Sales, EU Consumer Confidence, NZ Retail Sales, RBA’s Lowe, Fed’s Powell, Evans, Rosengren, ECB’s BoE’s Carney, ECB’s de Guindos, Riksbank’s Floden, Earnings; Home Depot

* US CHINA TRADE:  China Foreign Minister Wang told US Secretary of State Pompeo in a call that while a trade deal between the two nations is still possible, China must protect its interests. Meanwhile, the PBOC's Q1 monetary policy report continues to get attention; the report said that escalating tensions could destabilise the world economy, and the central bank pledged to continue its targeted stimulus measures while keeping the yuan stable. China Global Times Editor tweeted that the banning of Huawei is a "turning point of the US semiconductor companies gradually losing Chinese market".

* GEOPOLITICAL: After hawkish rhetoric from the Iranian Revolutionary Guard last week, US President Trump warned Iran to "never threaten the United States again!" US Senator Lindsey Graham later commented that, at a briefing with National Security Adviser Bolton regarding Iran, "it is clear that over the last several weeks Iran has attacked pipelines and ships of other nations and created threat streams against American interests" and "if the Iranian threats against American personnel and interests are activated we must deliver an overwhelming military response," maintaining the tension built throughout last week. It was also reported on Monday that Iran had increased – by fourfold – its uranium enrichment process, where it notified the UN that it was disregarding the 300KG production cap specified in the previous nuclear deal, adding cadence to the US hawk view that the country poses a risk from its nuclear ambitions, a textbook line used in justification of previous US military intervention. Later reports suggested that Saudi Air Defence has intercepted two Houthi missiles in the Mecca province; the Saudis had previously accused the Houthis as being used as a proxy by Iran, who attacked its oil pumping stations last week.

* BREXIT: UK opposition leader Corbyn in an interview on Sunday moved closer to giving the UK public a vote on any Brexit deal. On the Tory leadership battle, around 60 members of the Conservative party have banded together to stop ex-Foreign Minister (and current front-runner) Boris Johnson from succeeding May and pursuing a no-deal Brexit. Mid-session, ITV’s Brand reported that Brexit indicative votes are 100% dead and buried with all focus now on the Withdrawal Agreement Bill and what the government can do to get MPs on board.

* FED: Fed’s Bostic (Non-Voter, Dove) said that, as his base case, the US economy will continue to perform with solid growth this year whilst reiterating the Fed narrative that he doesn’t expect a rate cut imminently and does not see one by September, nor does he have a cutting or hiking bias at the moment. Fed's Harker (Non-voter, Dovish) commented that the US economy will not grow faster than 2% without further efforts to connect employers and labour. Fed's Bullard (Dove, Voter) said the US economy is performing quite well, but if inflation remains beneath target (at 1.6%) he would be more aggressively in favour for lowering rates. Fed's Clarida (Voter, Neutral) largely repeated comments from previous monetary policy speeches and repeated that the economy is operating at or close to the Fed's twin mandate. Fed's Williams (Voter, Neutral) commented that policy makers ought to maintain a strong labour market and keep inflation low and that the Fed has changed its view on how low unemployment can get without sparking inflation pressures, whilst also noting that the Fed wants to maintain the expansion as long as possible (NOTE: last week Williams suggested the Fed needed to get inflation to target, and to stay there).

* PRIMER - RBA minutes overnight will likely be overshadowed Governor Lowe proceeding comments: A surprise win for the Liberal-National coalition sees AUD rise; desks remind us that RBA mins overnight are not likely to be hawkish or neutral; RBA still seen cutting its Cash Rate (given its 'tests' have already been met), perhaps as early as June, but there are now risks that if there is an upswing in the economy underpinned by tax cuts, improving business confidence as well as a better news on the property front, RBA could push any subsequent rate cut back. Participants expect the minutes to provide some "meat on the bones" regarding the threshold for the RBA to loosen policy (a rising unemployment rate was one of its conditions, which has been satisfied). The main event however will be the RBA Governor Lowe’s speech, entitled “The Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy” with some desks expecting the governor to use the speech to pave the way for rate cut in June. Westpac notes that there is an approximately 70% probability of a 25bp rate cut factored-in for the RBA’s next Board meeting on June 4. "The market is focused on the fact that the RBA has noted that 'a further improvement in the labour market was likely needed for inflation to be consistent with the target.' With unemployment rising from 5.0% to 5.1% and now 5.2%, and underemployment near a record level, the market is convinced that there is sufficient momentum to dash the RBA’s hopes of an improvement," Westpac writes. "Of course, in the communication post the May Board meeting, the Governor also stated that '…the Board will be paying close attention to developments in the labour market at its upcoming meetings'." Westpac says that the key question is whether the RBA will have lost patience rather than wait for further evidence over the next few months. The Federal election has also returned the incumbent Government in a surprise result. "Given that it resolves some policy uncertainty and fears about the opposition’s potential policy impact on growth, the AUD has rallied and forward RBA pricing has been pared back slightly. Beyond that initial response, however, we see the result as ensuring “business as usual” in AU fixed income markets."

* AUSTRIA ELECTIONS: Austrian Chancellor Kurz has signalled he is preparing for elections in September, after scandal broke over the weekend where it was revealed that Vice Chancellor Strache (who has stepped down) was filmed promising favours in exchange support and financing to win the 2017 elections. It was later reported that all ministers from the Austrian far-right were to leave the government, according to the Austrian news agency APA. As yet, Kurz is to officially decide whether he will disband the coalition and rule as a minority government or carry on. Analysts will be watching to see if this development has any implications for the European Elections (23-26 May) amid the suggestion of foreign influence benefiting far-right Parties.

* WTI (M9) SETTLES 0.34 HIGHER AT 63.10/BBL, BRENT (N9) SETTLES 0.24 LOWER AT 71.97/BBL. The crude complex failed to hold on to its earlier surge higher on Monday as US traders took to their desks, where a bearish demand environment weighed on the bullish supply signals. Following the OPEC+ JMMC meeting over the weekend, headlines suggested members had agreed to sustained production cuts, although the stances were not that black and white. For instance, Russia did not rule out an increase in production, where Energy Minister Novak provided more neutral comments in comparison to other key members present, such as Saudi Arabia which highlighted the cartel’s consensus for sustained cuts. Nonetheless, crude legged higher on the opening of futures for the week, with bulls running on the sustained cuts and Middle East supply risk narrative. However, as the European session commenced, chatter of a breakdown in US-China trade talks catalysed a risk off sentiment seeing crude, alongside equities, retreat from highs. Elsewhere on Monday, OPEC is reportedly considering delaying the Vienna meeting from June 25th to early July; this follows reported comments from oil figureheads at the weekend JMMC meeting that more data is needed to make the decision on whether to extend the cuts, it is not specified whether this was the reason.

S&P 500 -0.7% at 2840, NASDAQ-100 -1.7% at 7377, Dow Jones -0.3% at 25680, SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary -0.7%, Consumer Staples -0.2%, Energy 0.1%, Financials 0.1%, Health Care 0%, Industrials -0.3%, Information Technology -1.8%, Materials -1.5%, Telecommunication Services -1.2%, Utilities 0.2%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: T-Mobile (TMUS) and Sprint (S) jumped higher at the open on the news that the two telecoms cos are to offer concessions to the US Government to help secure regulatory approval for their planned merger which could include asset sales and rural-service guarantees. The two stocks later saw some downside on reports that the DoJ is to stand against the approval of the merger, but ultimately both stocks finished the session higher. Vodafone (VOD) and Verizon (VZ) moved higher in sympathy. United Parcel Services (UPS) saw some downside after reports emerged that SCOTUS denied a hearing for the co over Postal Service delivery prices. Cisco (CSCO) was unable to recover premarket losses despite news emerging that the held preliminary acquisition talks with cloud start-up HashiCorp, but did perform better than the majority of the Semiconductor sector. Nielsen (NLSN) spiked higher as news emerged that the co are said to be looked at by private equity, sources say; deal in high 20s seen as very likely, and could come in a few weeks. Apple (AAPL) opened lower after HSBC lowered its profit target for the co, citing renewed China growth risk and the negative impact of tariffs. Intel (INTC), Qualcomm (QCOM), ASML Holdings (ASML), Xilinx (XLNX) all opened lower as the semiconductor index suffered on renewed worries regarding the US/China trade dispute. Broadcom (AVGO) opened lower with the wider semiconductor industry, and saw further downside on reports that chip sales are being probed by the US FCC, with the probe focusing on its WiFi and Switch-Chip sales. Baidu (BIDU) took a hit as Susquehanna slashed their price target for the co.

* US T-Note futures settle ticks 6+ lower at 124-09: Overnight, a better than expected Japanese GDP report for Q1 lent negative ticks in the Treasury complex, and while buyers stepped in at the European open, following more global trade tensions related news flow, the positive start for European equities capped hte Treasury upside, and futures were flat as NY entered. The complex then began its gradual drift lower, and are heading into APAC lower, led by the belly; major curve spreads were mixed into the close, but moves were +/- 1bps or so.

* FX WRAP: USD was range bound through US trade, unmoved by a heavy slate of Fed speak which failed to deviate significantly from the Fed’s neutral line and cautious ahead of Wednesdays FOMC minutes; DXY hovering just below 98.00. Equally, EUR was fairly flat, if not a touch stronger vs USD, taking a similarly cautious tone ahead of this week’s ECB minutes and speakers. JPY was mixed; a decent GDP headline, though some have concerns about the composition of growth, and think some payback might be seen in quarters ahead; real exports and imports both contracted in the quarter reflecting weakness in the external environment amid slowing global demand. GBP was flat, as sterling awaits the next round of developments on the Brexit front, and various BoE speaker pencilled in for the week. AUD: surprise win for the Liberal-National coalition sees AUD rise, and attention moves now to RBA minutes overnight, as well as a speech from Governor Lowe. CNY: PBOC deputy governor Pan over the weekend said the yuan would remain stable due to sound economic fundamentals, who said that the sound and healthy operation of the Chinese economy and finance has been providing solid support for the FX market and the yuan to keep stable at a reasonable level. Although gapping higher vs USD over the weekend, USDCNY was not able to reclaim the 6.9000 level in Monday trade. INR: Exit polls have indicated that PM Modi will likely win a second term, building on his Parliamentary majority (final results due 23 May).

Daily FX Wrap: Dollar drifts and Aussie pares post-election gains into RBA minutes
content:
USD

The Greenback is consolidating after last week’s rally on upbeat surveys and some decent data, as US-China trade wars continue amidst strained relations since the end of formal talks and Washington blacklisted Huawei and ZTE. However, the DXY is holding a tight line around the 98.000 level with resistance capping the upside between 98.035-102 (Fib and mtd peak) and little on the downside below the 97.892 session low before 97.500 and then last Wednesday’s intraday base at 97.436.

AUD

The Aussie remans well ahead of its G10 peers, but has whittled overnight gains made on the surprise weekend election results that handed an unlikely victory to PM Morrison’s Liberal-led coalition as attention switches to the RBA and minutes that could add more fuel to easing expectations for next month’s policy meeting. Aud/Usd is slipping back towards 0.6900 within a 0.6938-0.6890 range and Aud/NZD is now nearer the middle of its 1.0602-1.0559 band, as the Kiwi continues track its antipodean counterpart in the absence of any real independent drivers, with Nzd/Usd meandering between 0.6550-20.

CAD/CHF

The next best majors, with the Loonie getting a double boost from positive US-Canada-Mexico tariff reports and a rebound in oil prices. Usd/Cad has retreated further from last week’s 1.3500+ highs towards 1.3400 where bids are anticipated ahead of Canadian retail sales data on Wednesday and the return of market participants after today’s Victoria Day holiday. Meanwhile, the Franc has rebounded to circa 1.0080 from 1.0120 vs the Buck and further away from 1.1300 against the Euro, prompting some SNB acknowledgement via another reminder that intervention is an option if needed.

GBP/EUR/JPY 

The laggards or at least unable to really take advantage of the Usd downturn, as Cable remains wary about Brexit and political risk and topped out short of 1.2760 before drifting back down to low 1.2720 area, while Eur/Gbp meanders between 0.8777-50 on an almost equally sluggish single currency. Indeed, Eur/Usd laboured in a tight 1.1151-69 range ahead of the EU Parliamentary elections, through yet more calls from Italy to change, loosen or scrap the fiscal rules and after Austria’s Government collapsed. Elsewhere, Usd/Jpy recoiled from 110.31 to 109.81 as the broad risk mood turned sour again, and after hitting highs overnight on much better than expected Japanese GDP data.

EM

Usd/Try has pulled up around 6.0800 and eased back towards 6.0000 following reports that the Government is ‘leaning’ on Turkish banks to support debt auctions, and despite President Erdogan hinting that S-400 missiles may be bought from Russia before July, but Usd/Brl is nudging resistance up near 4.1000 as Brazil’s Pension Head Marinho noted opposition to certain elements of the reform bill and hinted at changes to the proposal to try end ensure in passes.

US chipmakers, including Intel (INTC), Qualcomm (QCOM), Xilinx (XLNX), Broadcom (AVGO), will comply with the US’s Huawei ban, and have informed employees that they will no longer supply the Chinese telecoms giant until further notice whilst Infineon (IFNNY), STMicroelectronics (STM) and Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) and have already halted shipments or cut off services. Moreover, Analog Devices (ADI) is at risk to the Huawei ban due to its high exposure to 5G, according to RBC, who also write cautiously on Synopsys (SNPS) and Cadence (CDNS), which have exposure to ZTE, the other Chinese co. at risk of a ban.

Applied Materials (AMAT), BorgWarner (BWA), Charles Schwab (SCHW), Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN), Tapestry (TPR) and Take-Two (TTWO) all saw positive mentions in this week's edition of Barron's.

DOW

Apple (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals), Dell (DELL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) and two other technology companies are to sell their preferred shares back to Toshiba Memory by the end of May, worth up to USD 4.5bln. Separately, HSBC cut its price target for the iPhone maker from USD 180 to USD 174, citing renewed China growth risk and the negative effect of tariffs. HSBC suggested that if tariffs affect imported Apple products to the US then the co may have to raise prices, which could have dire consequences on demand.

Boeing (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) said it had made a correction to its simulation software, which mimics the 737 MAX, after reports emerged that software used on the aircraft simulator is unable to reproduce some flying conditions, including those which led to the recent fatal crash in Ethiopia. Elsewhere, Boeing has reportedly emerged victorious against competitor Airbus (AIR FP) for the order of a wide-body jet from Air New Zealand, an 18-month long competition.

Disney’s (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) Marvel Entertainment will enter into a strategic partnership with NetEase (NTES) to produce original content based on the existing Marvel franchise.

ExxonMobil (XOM) (Energy/Integrated Oil & Gas) has evacuated all of its foreign staff from the West Qurna 1 Oilfield in Iraq, days after the US evacuated non-essential staff from its Iraqi embassy in Baghdad. This adds strain to the energy co’s proposed deal with Iraq on the South Integrated Project.

Nike (NKE) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel, Accessories & Luxury Goods) is set to add new terms to its contracts with female athletes, providing them with better support them during pregnancy.

NASDAQ 100

Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) will comply with the Trump administrations ban on doing business with Huawei and have cut off the supply of hardware and some software services to the Chinese telecoms giant. Huawei phones will now not feature key Google software and will have to use an opensource version of Google’s Android technology. Elsewhere, Alphabet are to shut down its Jump Virtual Reality video program, citing the emergence of a number of alternative solutions for creators as causing a decline in usage.

T-Mobile US (TMUS) (Communications Services/Wireless Telecommunication Services) and Sprint (S) (Communications Services/Wireless Telecommunication Services) are to offer concessions to the US Government to help secure regulatory approval for their planned merger which could include asset sales and rural-service guarantees.

Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) – Wedbush raised concerns regarding underlying demand for the electric automakers Model 3 in the US, analyst Daniel Ives lowered his PT to USD 230 from USD 275.

Wynn Resorts (WYNN) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Restaurants & Leisure), MGM Resorts (MGM) – Wynn Resorts is in talks to divest its USD 2.6bln casino project near Boston to MGM. The casino is due to open in June, Wynn has said the preliminary talks will not affect the opening.

S&P 500

CBS (CBS) (Communication Services/Media), Lions Gate Entertainment (LGF.A) (Communications Services/Entertainment) – CBS has reportedly made an informal bid for Lions Gate’s cable network, Starz, coming after Lions Gate rejected a previous USD 5bln offer a couple of months ago from CBS.

DowDuPont (DWDP) (Materials/Specialty Chemicals) – Morgan Stanley cut their profit target and earnings forecast for the industrial conglomerate. The investment bank cited a weakening of economic conditions as a potential challenge to DowDuPont’s operations and management’s ability to optimise the structure of the conglomerate through strategic activity.

Target (TGT) (Consumer Discretionary/General Merchandise Stores) have been upgraded to equal weight at Morgan Stanley, citing the 15% pullback in the co’s share price over the past few months as limiting near term downside.

OTHER

Lumentum (LITE) (Information Technology/Communications Equipment), an Apple supplier, cut their Q4 forecast after the co. discontinued all shipments to Huawei, saying they cannot predict when shipments will resume.

Lyft (LYFT) (Industrials/Road & Rail) has had a lawsuit filed against it by an investor group, who allege the newly public ride hailing app mislead investors about its market positioning.

Toyota (TM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) have condemned the Trump administration’s position on potential auto-tariffs for foreign based automakers, saying “today's Executive Proclamation is a major set-back for American consumers, workers and the auto industry.”

Uber Technologies (UBER) (Industrials/Road & Rail), WSJ reports that large pre-IPO investors, such as Blackrock (BLK) and Tiger Global Management, undermined the ride hailing app’s IPO by passing on the option to acquire more stock in the offering.

subject: Talking Crude: JMMC lean towards sustained cuts
content:
• The crude complex has begun the week on the front foot with thanks to suggestions of sustained OPEC+ production cuts, in addition to the geopolitical risk premium, where President Trump recently said that any conflict with Iran would be the “official end” of that country. It is worth noting that prices have been coming off their highs previously in the session, seemingly falling in-line with revived US-China trade tensions.
  • After the JMMC meeting on Sunday, Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih said that there remained consensus among OPEC members to continue production curbs; however, Russian Energy Minister Novak seemed to suggest that other options were available in H219, including a possible raising of output levels. Novak added that if there turns out to be a shortfall in the market, then Russia would be prepared to examine options linked with a possible increase in production.
  • Elsewhere, the JMMC said that compliance with the supply cut deal was running at a clip of 168% in April (average compliance since January has been around 120%). Furthermore, sources noted that the Russian and Saudi oil figureheads reportedly discussed two options for June. The first scenario would see an elimination of over compliance currently over 150%, equating to an output cuts just under 2mln BPD, according to calculations. This would mean a continuation of the current deal and an increase in production of around 0.8mln BPD. The second scenario would see an ease of the agreed cuts to 0.9mln BPD from 1.2mln BPD.  Analysts at ING do not believe that the output cut deal will continue in its current form, with their balance sheets showing “significant tightening” heading into Q3.
  • Baker Hughes reported US oil rigs falling to their lowest count since March 2018 for the previous week, with online rigs falling nearly 10% since their peak in November 2018. This comes amidst a more cash conscious US shale industry, “The yesteryears of credit-fuelled splurges are a thing of the past and financial discipline has taken precedence over supply growth,” analysts at PVM so eloquently note, giving credence to the supply-driven bull thesis dominating the market this year. However, PVM caveat that the Shale industry is heavily dependent on its drilled but uncompleted wells (DUCs), which “represent a cost-effective and readily available source of supply that can be brought online in a short amount of time,” a somewhat alternative to drilling activity.

Nomura quants say systematic selling pressure is gradually lightening
content:
• Friday's fall in US equities looks to be a temporary reaction to the rebound in US stocks over the previous few days, Nomura says; Nomura's own sentiment index pulled-out of negative (risk-averse) territory, but the bank says outlook for risk-taking still looks unstable.
  • While CTAs still seem to be watching for opportunities to unwind their long positions in US equity futures, they are currently in wait-and-see mode, Nomura says. !With the S&P 500 above around 2820, we see less risk that Commodity Trading Advisors (CTAs) will sell off stock to cut their losses," which says that by the same token, "with the index steadily below around 2910, a resurgence of mechanistic upside-chasing also looks unlikely."
  • Nomura says "that given the current supply-demand balance, the US equity market this week looks likely to be influenced less by trend-following trading based on systematic rules than by fundamental trading based on discretionary calls."
  • Nomura says that most most hedge funds seem not to be factoring in risk of another plunge in US stocks. "One thing we notice when looking over movements in the US equity market through last week is the rapid closing out of positions hedging against share price downside (that is, against a sharp rise in the VIX)," which can be seen, for example, in the drop in the call/put ratio for VIX options. "Investors look to have locked in profits on their long VIX calls (premised on a rise in the VIX)," the bank writes, "this rollback of downside hedges may have indirectly supported the US equity rebound." As a result, US equity exposure at hedge funds overall has turned upward again.
  • "The majority of hedge funds, cautious of the risk of a correction in the US market, seem to have intentionally held down their exposure to US stocks in April. But they also seem to have cleared away their downside hedge positions (long VIX calls and shorts on US stocks) all at once as the market followed the 'sell in May' adage," Nomura writes, "of course, this also means hedge funds have left themselves defenseless in the event of another sharp drop in US stocks." The bank also notes that it appears that the majority of hedge funds do not expect another sharp rise in volatility, and that they have concluded that the correction has run its course.
  • Nomura, looking at scenarios for the coming weeks and into June, says to focus on risk of market readjustment and HFs' appetite for risk. "From that perspective, we think from here through the end of May will be an important period during which the degree of resilience of US equities and global stocks will be put to the test," Nomura says, "based on the pattern in global equity sentiment and risk-parity funds' standard month-end rebalancing, we see a risk of global equities readjusting after a dead-cat bounce." However, nomura says that even if stock prices were to readjust, so long as hedge fund appetite for risk-taking is intact, it thinks that buying on dips may gain momentum and thereby help put the US equity and global equity markets on more solid footing in June.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 20th May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European Indices [Euro Stoxx 50 -1.2%] have continued to move lower, after a relatively uneventful opening, with the downside stemming from unconfirmed negative reports on US-China trade
  • In FX, the USD is subdued vs all G10 counterparts in particular the AUD following PM Morrison’s surprise victory
  • Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih, at the JMMC, stated that there is consensus to gently drive inventories down and that Saudi Arabia see no need to quickly boost production with oil around USD 70/bbl
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Fed’s Harker, Clarida, Williams, BoE’s Broadbent and Riksbank’s Skingsley

 

ASIA-PAC

Asia equity markets were somewhat mixed as lingering trade uncertainty clouded over a buoyant start to the week. ASX 200 (+1.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) were rampant at the open with the Australian benchmark at its highest since 2007 following a surprise win by PM Morrison’s ruling Coalition which defied the opinion polls to beat the Labor party and even reportedly secured a majority, while Tokyo sentiment was underpinned by a weaker currency and after much better than expected GDP growth for Q1. However, some of the gains were later pared as China entered the fray in which Shanghai Comp (-0.4%) and Hang Seng (-0.6%) resumed their losses amid US-China trade tensions after reports suggested negotiations were in flux and that talks have stalled, while comments from China were also concerning as Foreign Minister Wang warned the US to not go too far. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid a lack of demand for safe-havens in Japan and after the better than expected GDP numbers, while an enhanced-liquidity auction for longer-dated bonds also saw slightly weaker demand from prior.

China Foreign Minister Wang Yi said recent words and actions by US have harmed interests of China and its enterprises, while he added that China oppose these actions and warned the US to not go too far. Wang added that the trade dispute must be solved through negotiation on an equal footing and hopes both sides will avoid escalating tensions. (Newswires)

A People's Daily Op-Ed said US intellectual property complaints are a political tool intended to suppress China's economic development. (Twitter/ People's Daily)

Chinese President Xi visited a major rare earth mining and processing facility today amid growing discussions that China could consider banning the export of such minerals as part of the US-China trade war, according to SCMP. (SCMP)

PBoC state they will launch a pilot bond mutual fund which can be traded on stock exchanges or interbank markets. (Newswires)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8988 (Prev. 6.8859)

Japanese GDP (Q1) Q/Q 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.0% (Prev. 0.5%, Rev. 0.4%). (Newswires) Japanese GDP (Q1) Y/Y 2.1% vs. Exp. -0.2% (Prev. 1.9%, Rev. 1.6%)

 

UK/EU

UK PM May said the Brexit withdrawal agreement bill will have an improved package of measures according to an Op Ed, however there were separate reports that her new offer to UK lawmakers contains nothing new on customs arrangement and retains the Northern Irish backstop. (Sunday Times/Telegraph)

UK Brexit Secretary has warned that no-deal preparations should be brought forward ‘at pace’ if MPs do not back PM May’s deal. (Sky News)

UK Cabinet are to discuss a new Brexit deal tomorrow and will decide on whether there will be indicative votes on customs, according to BBC's Political Correspondent Watson. (Twitter)

ECB’s Knot commented that Eurozone inflation is not where the central bank wants it. (Newswires)

Austria Chancellor Kurz called for snap election in September following resignation of coalition partner and Vice Chancellor Strache resigned. (Newswires)

Italian Cabinet Secretary Giorgetti says the League's loyalty to the 5 Star Movement can not go on forever. (Newswires) Subsequently, Italy's Economy Minister Tria states that it impossible to stick deficit/debt commitments while reducing taxed and increasing spending, as such the government will need to choose; public debt is sustainable, spread levels are ecessive and the government must retain control. While Deputy PM Salvini states that the only way to lower debt is to reduce taxes in order to increase growth.

 

US

 

Just after 09:00BST there were unverified rumours published via @Money_China implying that there had been a break down in US-China trade discussions, and that China will suspend business with all suppliers who have agreed to halt supplying Huawei. RANsquawk have not been able to verify these comments as such we are currently giving them no credence.

US President Trump said beginning on Monday, US farmers can resume business with Mexico and Canada as both have taken the tariff penalties off US agricultural products. This follows reports on Friday that a deal was said to have been reached for US to lift tariffs on steel & aluminium from Canada and Mexico, while a Mexican Official said Mexico and Canada will lift retaliatory tariffs on US products once the US announces a deal on lifting tariffs on metal import. (Washington Post)

 

GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump stated it would be the official end of Iran if the country wants to fight, while he warned Iran to never threaten the US again. (Twitter)

Turkey’s President Erdogan has stated that Russian may bring forward the delivery date of S-400’s from June and has ruled out demands from the US to delay purchase of the S-400 system. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities have kicked off the week on the backfoot [Eurostoxx 50 -1.2%] following on from a mixed lead in Asia with sentiment in Europe dampened on speculation that China will retaliate against Huawei measures [NOTE: THIS IS UNVERIFIED] after Google suspended Huawei from Android access. As such, broad based losses are seen across European equities with Italy’s FTSE MIB (-2.0%) the clear laggard amid a slew of large cap ex-divs. Sectors are mostly lower with defensive sectors buoyed by the risk-averse tone whilst energy names are supported by the price action in the complex. On the downside, material and IT names are the clear underperformers with the former subdued by price action in base metals. Meanwhile, the latter is pressured amid a decline in semiconductor names following reports via the Nikkei that Infineon (-4.6%) reportedly halted shipments to Huawei, in turn moving fellow chip names lower in sympathy including Dialog Semiconductor (-3.4%), ASM (-3.0%) and STMicroelectronics (-8.3%).  On the flip side, the aforementioned Google/Huawei news supported Huawei’s European competitors with Nokia (+2.0%) and Ericsson (+1.0%) shares underpinned by the reports. Finally, in terms of individual movers, Ryanair (-2.7%) fell as much as 5% at the open following earnings coupled with a downbeat fares outlook. Elsewhere, Deutsche Bank (-3.0%) shares slid after anti-money laundering specialists at the Co. flagged up suspicious financial transactions involving legal entities controlled by US President Trump and his son-in-law Kushner. Turning to some analysis from Nomura, Quant Insights note that CTAs seem to be looking for opportunities to unwind long positions in US equity futures. Nomura also predicts that this week, US equities “looks likely to be influenced less by trend-following trading based on systematic rules than by fundamental trading based on discretionary calls.”, given the current supply/demand balance.

Apple (AAPL) - HSBC have cut the Co's price target to USD 174 from USD 180, have also cut the Co's operating margins to account for Q3 outlook and have cut their outlook on Iphone sales.

FX

AUD - A sharp rebound from recent multi-month lows vs its US counterpart following the weekend Australian election that saw PM Morrison upset the pre-vote odds to secure a 3rd term in office and his coalition gain a majority over the Labour Party. Aud/Usd has reclaimed 0.6900+ status in response having traded down to 0.6862 last week in wake of disappointing jobs data that heightened the prospect of a June RBA rate cut.

 

NZD - The next best G10 currency as the Kiwi catches a bid on the coattails of its antipodean peer, albeit hampered by Aud/Nzd cross-flows up to 1.0600 at one stage. Nevertheless, Nzd/Usd hit a 0.6550 overnight high compared to 0.6521 at worst and last week’s 0.6512 base (Friday), as the US Dollar loses momentum broadly after its post-data/survey and China trade war related rally. On that note, the DXY has topped out just above 98.000 and ahead of resistance including a 98.035 Fib and the early May high of 98.102.

 

GBP - The Pound has also pared some losses partly on the aforementioned Dollar downturn, but also against a lagging Euro, with Cable bouncing off a 1.2723 trough to just over 1.2750 and Eur/Gbp easing back to 0.8750 from 0.8775. Brexit and UK political uncertainty are still to the fore, but Sterling appears to be benefiting from some short covering/profit taking alongside technical buying, with a Fib in the cross sitting at 0.8779.

 

CHF/CAD - Also benefiting from the Buck fade, as the Franc rebounds through 1.0100 and Loonie further from 1.3500+ lows amidst more reports that a deal is done to lift US steel and aluminium tariffs. The Cad may also be gleaning traction from a post-JMMC bounce in crude prices, like the NOK, which is outperforming its Scandi rival with the Eur cross back down under 9.8000 vs Eur/Sek at 10.7600.

 

EUR/JPY - As noted above, the single currency is a relative underperformer as Eur/Usd struggles to recover between 1.1168-51 parameters despite reports of bids/support at 1.1150 protecting near term support at 1.1135 and the 1.1112 ytd low. Decent option expiry interest may be keeping the headline pair in check given almost 1 bn running off from 1.1150 to 1.1160 at today’s NY cut, while chart resistance resides at 1.1190-1.1200 in the form of 100 and 200 HMAs. Meanwhile, the Yen has lost a bit more of its safe-haven allure following overnight Japanese Q1 GDP that topped consensus considerably, with Usd/Jpy up over 110.00 and as high as 110.31 at one stage.

 

EM - The Turkish Lira has failed to sustain recovery gains towards 6.0000 and higher vs the Greenback yet again after weekend comments from President Erdogan suggesting that it may bring forward its planned purchase of S-400 missiles from Russia rather than delaying the order amidst opposition and the threat of sanctions from the US.

 

Australia’s ruling Coalition led by PM Morrison is set to remain in power for a 3rd consecutive term following the Federal election on Saturday with the incumbents having at least 75 seats vs. 67 seats for Labor, while other reports suggested that the Coalition has managed to obtain a majority. (News.com.au)

 

FIXED INCOME

Several potential factors behind a sprited recovery in Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries including more US-China-global trade jitters and a retreat in stocks, oil prices and Italian debt, while the latest Buba monthly report is hardly encouraging. The respective 10 year benchmarks are still looking top heavy or leggy, but the German bond just hit a marginal new Eurex high at 167.07 (+1 tick vs -43 ticks), while its UK and US equivalents are both flat vs -29 and -6+ ticks at worst. Ahead, April’s national activity index and Fed speakers including Harker, Clarida (twice) and Williams.

 

COMMODITIES

The energy complex is ultimately in the green, albeit off highs, as sentiment dampened amidst unconfirmed reports of a deteriorating relationship between US and China. WTI (+0.2%) and Brent (+0.4%) prices are underpinned in the aftermath of the JMMC meeting as key oil figureheads noted that concerns of rising stockpiles outweighed supply issues from Iran and Venezuela. Thus, energy ministers hinted at their dedication to extend the OPEC+ output pact beyond June, although any revisions to the current deal will be decided at next months meeting. Rhetoric from the energy ministers deviated slightly, with sources stating that Saudi Arabia is in no rush to increase production as the Kingdom is satisfied with oil around USD 70/bbl, whilst its Russian counterpart noted that all options are still on the table ahead of June, including a hike in production. Furthermore, sources noted that the Russian and Saudi oil figureheads reportedly discussed two options for June. The first scenario would see an elimination of over compliance currently over 150%, equating to an output cuts just under 2mln BPD, according to calculations. This would mean a continuation of the current deal and an increase in production of around 0.8mln BPD. The second scenario would see an ease of the agreed cuts to 0.9mln BPD from 1.2mln BPD.  Analysts at ING do not believe that the output cut deal will continue in its current form, with their balance sheets showing “significant tightening” heading into Q3. On a technical front, WTI prices hover just above their 21 DMA (62.93) while Brent straddles around the psychological USD 72.50/bbl mark ahead of its 21 DMA (71.80). Elsewhere, gold (-0.2%) prices lost more ground to the rising Buck with prices now flirting with the 1275/oz mark. Meanwhile, copper prices extended losses amid the souring risk tone given the aforementioned unconfirmed reports regard US/China. Furthermore, last week money managers increased their net short positions in COMEX copper by almost 8.5k lots, holding a net short of 35.3k lots, whilst speculators increase gross shorts by 4.8k lots and liquidated 3.6k gross long positions over the week.

Baker Hughes (May 17): oil rigs -3 at 802, nat gas rigs +2 at 185, US total rigs -1 at 987. (Newswires)

Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih stated that there is consensus to drive down inventories gently and Saudi Arabia sees no need to boost production quickly now with oil at around USD 70/bbl, while Kuwait Oil Minister said OPEC+ countries’ compliance to oil output cuts is very large and assured Kuwait’s continued cooperation as well as commitment to output agreement to create balance in the market. (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia and Russia are said to be discussing two main scenarios for a meeting of OPEC/Non-OPEC in June and both frameworks propose raising crude output from the second half of 2019, according to sources familiar with the matter. (Newswires)

OPEC+ cut compliance was about 150% in April according to delegates, while there were also reports that Iranian crude exports have fallen to 500k BPD or lower since the imposition of new tariffs. (Newswires)

Equinor say they are investigating the source of an oil leak at the Statfjord loading buoy; offloading is taking place via an alternative buoy, output unaffected. (Newswires)

content: Gilts gapped down off Monday’s open and dipped a bit further to a 128.84 low vs their previous 128.92 settlement, but like Short Sterling contracts the 10 year bond was more resilient than counterparts in early trade with a brief rebound into positive territory at 128.96 while Bunds retreated to 166.87. However, core bonds and 3 month strips have succumbed to more sustained if not heavy selling pressure since, with Gilts down to 128.63 (-29 ticks), Bunds just off a 166.63 low (-43 ticks) and Short Sterling -3 ticks at worst vs +1.5 ticks earlier. No obvious catalyst for the abrupt downturn, but EU stocks are paring losses and Italian BTPs are outperforming. Ahead, no UK data, but a speech from BoE’s Broadbent after hours.

subject: JMMC: The Key Takeaways
content:
*OVERVIEW: The energy complex gapped higher at the open in the aftermath of the JMMC meeting in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, as key oil figureheads noted that concerns of rising stockpiles outweighed supply issues from Iran and Venezuela. Thus, energy ministers hinted at dedication to extend the OPEC+ output pact (1.2mln BPD reduction from October levels; 0.8mln BPD from OPEC and 0.4mln BPD from its allies) past June 2019 with all eyes now set on June’s decisive meeting of the cartel.

*SAUDI ARABIA: The Kingdom’s energy minister commented that global oil supply is the plentiful and recommended driving oil inventories down, but the producers will have to wait for more data before making a firm decision. OPEC sources noted that Saudi sees no need to ramp up production quickly as the Kingdom is satisfied with oil prices around USD 70/bbl.

*RUSSIA: Energy minister Novak’s ambitions deviated slightly from his counterparts as he reminded markets that all options are still on the table heading into the June meeting, including increased production. Novak also highlighted the need for more data before a solid decision is made. Regarding the contaminated oil along the Druzhba pipeline (key conduit for crude into Eastern Europe and Germany), the energy minister noted that oil supplies to Poland will be available on Monday and that the contaminated oil would not affect its annual output forecast.

*UAE: The energy minister took a harder stance regarding an ease of production cuts, stating that “it was not the right decision” amid fears of an oil price collapse.

*JUNE MEETING: Eyes now turn to the main event (for energy markets) next month as the cartel and allies officially decide on either 1) an extension to the deal, 2) a revision to the deal or 3) an end to the pact. Sources noted that the Saudi energy minister and his Russian counterpart discussed two possible options. The first scenario would see an elimination of over compliance currently over 150%, equating to an output cuts just under 2mln BPD, according to calculations. This would mean a continuation of the current deal and an increase in production of around 0.8mln BPD. The second scenario would see an ease of the agreed cuts to 0.9mln BPD from 1.2mln BPD. Nonetheless, oil output data will be closely watched in the coming weeks for hints of which way OPEC and its allies may sway as they convene in Vienna on June 25/26.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

20th May 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets were somewhat mixed as lingering trade uncertainty clouded over a buoyant start to the week. ASX 200 (+1.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) were rampant at the open with the Australian benchmark at its highest since 2007 following a surprise win by PM Morrison’s ruling Coalition which defied the opinion polls to beat the Labor party and even reportedly secured a majority, while Tokyo sentiment was underpinned by a weaker currency and after much better than expected GDP growth for Q1. However, some of the gains were later pared as China entered the fray in which Shanghai Comp (-0.6%) and Hang Seng (-0.4%) resumed their losses amid US-China trade tensions after reports suggested negotiations were in flux and that talks have stalled, while comments from China were also concerning as Foreign Minister Wang warned the US to not go too far. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid a lack of demand for safe-havens in Japan and after the better than expected GDP numbers, while an enhanced-liquidity auction for longer-dated bonds also saw slightly weaker demand from prior.

FTSE

Ryanair (RYA LN) – FY profit after tax EUR 1.02bln vs. guided EUR 1.0-1.1bln. Revenue EUR 7.60bln vs. Prev. EUR 7.15bln. Co. forecast group profits to range between EUR 750-950mln vs. Co. Exp. EUR 977mln. FY ex-fuel costs +5% vs. guided +6%. Board has approved a EUR 700mln share buyback, split into two tranches (EUR 500mln/EUR 200mln). H1 bookings are slightly ahead of last year, fares are lower and company expects this to continue into H2. Co. anticipates that FY fuel-bill will rise. CFO notes that approximately 1mln passenger have been cut from schedule amid the delays in Boeing 737 Max delivers. CEO sees weak fares in the coming years. CEO also noted that the Co. could be interested in divestments related to Lufthansa (LHA GY) interest in Condor/Thomas Cook (TCG LN). (Newswires)

BAE Systems (BA/ LN)/ Babcock (BAB LN)/ Rolls-Royce (RR/ LN)/ Fincantieri (FCT IM) – Fincantieri and Daewoo Shipbuilding (042660 KS) have reportedly withdrawn from the competition for a GBP 1bln contract to build three new support vessels for the Royal Navy, according to sources. The bidders left include a consortium of BAE Systems, Babcock, Rolls-Royce and Cammel Laird, although sources noted a debate about whether the consortium should stay in. (FT)

Thomas Cook (TCG LN) – Co. said it has held discussions with a range of suppliers to reassure them it has “ample resources” to see it through the summer holidays. Separately one Nordic payment provider is in talks with the Co. to extend the length of time it holds on to customer payments before passing them on to the Co. (FT)

Metro Bank (MTRO LN) – Co. will cease hiring the architectural firm owned by the chairman’s wife amid several major proxy advisers’ and investors’ criticism over conflict of interest, (FT)

Fever Tree (FEVR LN) – Co. are launching their own range of pre-mixed gin & tonics. (Telegraph)

Daily Mail (DMGT LN) – Co. were unsuccessful in their takeover bid for Independent News & Media, which was acquired by Mediahuis for GBP 128mln. (Telegraph)

UK Telecom Names – The implementation of 5G network is being delayed by a minimum of two years amid a legal battle regarding the control of millions of lampposts. (The Guardian)

UK Energy Names – Energy UK’s head stated that an unnecessary restructuring or manoeuvre towards state ownership may jeopardise the sectors reinvestment, which would potentially result in increased costs. Elsewhere, National Grid (NG/ LN) CEO states that investors are showing increased concern around Labour’s plans (CityAm) Follows reports that Labour Leader Corbyn would seek to nationalise the energy sectors if he became PM.

UK Banking Names – Banks, and credit providers may have to increase the levy they pay to fund advice services for individuals who are in debt difficulties, with this increase being up to GBP 100mln. (Times)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Co. noted that it increase anti-financial crime staff and enhanced controls in recent years. Co also noted that it seriously complies with AML/BSA laws. (NYT/Newswires) 

Wirecard (WDI GY) – A internal spreadsheet from the Co. indicates that three partner companies contributed around half of sales and in excess of 90% of profits to the Co. in 2016 and the beginning of 2017. This file was referenced in a FT article from the previous month, and in response the Co’s CEO stated that the figures in question were not accurate and the three partner companies had a insignificant level of contribution. (FT)

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 20th May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian indices mixed with focus on Australian elections and reports that US-China trade talks have stalled
  • Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih stated that there is consensus to drive down inventories gently and Saudi Arabia sees no need to boost production quickly now with oil at around USD 70/bbl
  • Reports around UK PM May’s Brexit bill differ, some indicate it contains improved measures others that it contains nothing new and retains the Irish backstop
  • Looking ahead, highlights include ECB’s Praet, Fed’s Harker, Clarida, Williams, BoE’s Broadbent and Riksbank’s Skingsley

 

ASIA-PAC

Asia equity markets were somewhat mixed as lingering trade uncertainty clouded over a buoyant start to the week. ASX 200 (+1.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) were rampant at the open with the Australian benchmark at its highest since 2007 following a surprise win by PM Morrison’s ruling Coalition which defied the opinion polls to beat the Labor party and even reportedly secured a majority, while Tokyo sentiment was underpinned by a weaker currency and after much better than expected GDP growth for Q1. However, some of the gains were later pared as China entered the fray in which Shanghai Comp (-0.6%) and Hang Seng (-0.4%) resumed their losses amid US-China trade tensions after reports suggested negotiations were in flux and that talks have stalled, while comments from China were also concerning as Foreign Minister Wang warned the US to not go too far. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid a lack of demand for safe-havens in Japan and after the better than expected GDP numbers, while an enhanced-liquidity auction for longer-dated bonds also saw slightly weaker demand from prior.

The next round of US/China trade negotiations are reportedly "in flux" and talks are said to have stalled. (CNBC)

China Foreign Minister Wang Yi said recent words and actions by US have harmed interests of China and its enterprises, while he added that China oppose these actions and warned the US to not go too far. Wang added that the trade dispute must be solved through negotiation on an equal footing and hopes both sides will avoid escalating tensions. (Newswires)

China's Global Times said China will certainly retaliate to the barbaric suppression of Huawei and suggested that this is the unanimous attitude of officials and the Chinese people. In related news, People's Daily Op-Ed said US intellectual property complaints are a political tool intended to suppress China's economic development. (Twitter/ People's Daily)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8988 (Prev. 6.8859)

Japanese GDP (Q1) Q/Q 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.0% (Prev. 0.5%, Rev. 0.4%). (Newswires) Japanese GDP (Q1) Y/Y 2.1% vs. Exp. -0.2% (Prev. 1.9%, Rev. 1.6%)

 

UK/EU

UK PM May said the Brexit withdrawal agreement bill will have an improved package of measures according to an Op Ed, however there were separate reports that her new offer to UK lawmakers contains nothing new on customs arrangement and retains the Northern Irish backstop. (Sunday Times/Telegraph)

UK Brexit Secretary has warned that no-deal preparations should be brought forward ‘at pace’ in MPs do not back PM May’s deal. (Sky News)

ECB’s Knot commented that Eurozone inflation is not where the central bank wants it. (Newswires)

Austria Chancellor Kurz called for snap election in September following resignation of coalition partner and Vice Chancellor Strache resigned. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed Ireland at 'A+'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

UK Rightmove House Prices (May) M/M 0.9% (Prev. 1.1%). (Newswires) UK Rightmove House Prices (May) Y/Y 0.1% (Prev. -0.1%)

 

FX

 

The DXY was flat near last week’s highs around the 98.00 level amid feeble attempts by its European counterparts to recoup Friday’s losses with EUR/USD and GBP/USD firmly below the 1.1200 and 1.2800 handles respectively. Brexit-related headwinds continued to be a hindrance on GBP after cross-party talks between PM May’s government and opposition Labour collapsed. Furthermore, reports suggested scepticism on PM May’s new offer to UK lawmakers which contains nothing new on the customs arrangement and retains the Northern Irish backstop. USD/JPY extended above the 110.00 level on the risk appetite in Japan and antipodeans were also higher with outperformance in AUD/USD following PM Morrison’s election miracle. Elsewhere, MXN and CAD were mildly supported following reports that suggested US is to lift tariffs on steel & aluminium from Canada and Mexico, while USD/INR gapped below the 70.00 handle with INR boosted after exit polls suggested PM Modi and his BJP Party are on track to secure a 2nd consecutive term following their 7-phase election which finished over the weekend with the results to be declared on Thursday.

 

Australia’s ruling Coalition led by PM Morrison is set to remain in power for a 3rd consecutive term following the Federal election on Saturday with the incumbents having at least 75 seats vs. 67 seats for Labor, while other reports suggested that the Coalition has managed to obtain a majority. (News.com.au)

 

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were mixed with the energy complex the outperformer as both Brent crude and WTI crude futures rallied over 1.0% following the OPEC+ JMMC meeting on Sunday where Saudi Energy Minister Al Falid suggested that the consensus among producers is to drive down crude inventories gently and that an extension of the output cut agreement for H2 was the main option discussed, although they will meet in June for the final decision. Elsewhere, gold prices languished at Friday’s lows as the greenback remained firm, while copper prices were indecisive amid the mixed risk sentiment overnight.

Baker Hughes (May 17): oil rigs -3 at 802, nat gas rigs +2 at 185, US total rigs -1 at 987. (Newswires)

Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih stated that there is consensus to drive down inventories gently and Saudi Arabia sees no need to boost production quickly now with oil at around USD 70/bbl, while Kuwait Oil Minister said OPEC+ countries’ compliance to oil output cuts is very large and assured Kuwait’s continued cooperation as well as commitment to output agreement to create balance in the market. (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia and Russia are said to be discussing two main scenarios for a meeting of OPEC/Non-OPEC in June and both frameworks propose raising crude output from the second half of 2019, according to sources familiar with the matter. (Newswires)

OPEC+ cut compliance was about 150% in April according to delegates, while there were also reports that Iranian crude exports have fallen to 500k BPD or lower since the imposition of new tariffs. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump stated it would be the official end of Iran if the country wants to fight, while he warned Iran to never threaten the US again. (Twitter)

 

Turkey’s President Erdogan has stated that Russian may bring forward the delivery date of S-400’s from June and has ruled out demands from the US to delay purchase of the S-400 system. (Newswires) 

US

Treasury yields were lower, and the curve flattened a touch on Friday, after hawkish trade rhetoric out of China. Decent University of Michigan data brought the complex off highs in the US afternoon, and there was further downside on reports that the US would drop metals tariffs on Canadian and Mexican steel and aluminium. US T-Note futures settled 2 ticks higher at 124-15+.

US President Trump said beginning on Monday, US farmers can resume business with Mexico and Canada as both have taken the tariff penalties off US agricultural products. This follows reports on Friday that a deal was said to have been reached for US to lift tariffs on steel & aluminium from Canada and Mexico, while a Mexican Official said Mexico and Canada will lift retaliatory tariffs on US products once the US announces a deal on lifting tariffs on metal import. (Washington Post)

US President Trump stated the EU is treating the US worse than the US is treating the EU and suggested the US does love Europe but has to be careful. (Newswires)
